sentence.text: ﻿A 4 years old Egyptian male patient presented to LMSDC, NRC with multiple congenital anomalies, delayed walking, delayed speech and a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), which surgically corrected at the age of one and half years.
He was born to first cousin parents.
There was history of maternal gestational diabetes mellitus which was diagnosed in the 4th month of pregnancy, and was controlled with subcutaneous insulin untill the end of pregnancy.
Prenatal ultrasound revealed congenital heart disease at 16 weeks of pregnancy, bilateral talipes, and abnormal skull shape.

On physical examination, the patient had brachycephaly, trigonocephaly, dysmorphic features in the form of epicanthic folds, bilateral squint, broad nasal bridge, long philtrum, thick lips, and low set ears.
Both hands had brachydactyly and soft tissue syndactyly of 3rd and 4th fingers with medially deviated thumbs.
Bilateral genu valgum and talipes deformity with medially and posteriorly rotated feet were noted.
Both feet had preaxial polydactyly, soft tissue syndacyly and brachydactyly of all toes (Fig. 2B–G).
Orodental evaluation showed long philtrum, everted lower lip open bite and high arched palate.
Vineland scale revealed an IQ score of 75.
Anthropometric measurements showed height of 94.1 cm (−1.74 SD), weight of 18Kgm (+0.74 SD) and head circumference of 50.6 cm (−0.38 SD).
Scrotal ultrasound examination showed bilateral undescended testes.
Brain CT showed premature closure of metopic suture and brain MRI showed mild atrophic brain changes.
Chromosomal studies by conventional G-banded karyotype showed a normal male karyotype (46, XY).
